answers.author: [Unknown]
answers.text:
Hi Casimir, 
Thank you for your question! We have many great resources on the Knowledge Network devoted to helping the next generation of city managers. Below I have selected a few which I believe you will find especially helpful but there are other many others so please browse and Knowledge Network and as always feel free to ask any questions you may have. 
•   Post MPA Dilemma is an old question which received many responses regarding what to do about getting that first job after graduation from graduate school. http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/questions/question/21429
•   You could consider becoming a Local Government Management Fellow, the application deadline is December 9th, 2013 so you still have time to apply!http://icma.org/en/icma/career_network/career_development/lgmf_fellows/become_fellow
•   Find Internships and Fellowships, this map of the US of local government fellowship and internship opportunities shows some of the different ways you can get your foot in the local government door. http://icma.org/en/icma/career_network/job_seekers/interns
•   From Student to City Manager: Reflections of MPA Students and Aspiring City Managers is a collection of reflections written by recent graduate school graduateshttp://icma.org/en/Article/100043/From_Student_to_City_Manager_Reflections_of_MPA_Students_and_Aspiring_City_Managers
•   Your First Five Years in Local Government: Getting Started is a checklist of strategies for getting into and advancing in local government http://icma.org/en/icma/career_network/career_resources/news_reports_presentations/first_five_years
•   Try looking through the groups section of the website for groups that fit your needs. For examples there are groups like Northwest nextgen which you might find helpful if you are in/want to be in the northwest. This is just an example and there are many groups like this which may be good for networking on the Knowledge Network. http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/groups#GroupTabs=MostActive
•   In addition to documents I would suggest looking at these different topics for information and guidance: Career Resources, Next Generation of Managers, Professional Development, Internships, and Employee Recruitment. http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/topics
I hope you find these resources useful as you continue to look for employment! 
Best, 
Robin Saywitz 
ICMA Knowledge Network Intern 
rsaywitz@icma.org

answers.author: Jared Cobb
answers.text:
Casimir,
In addition to the above, I would  suggest checking the classifieds on the state municipal league websites. Many of them post internships. I also wouldn't limit yourself to an internship; some cities are willing to train Budget/Management Analysts. Put yourself out there and always follow-up.
Here are two smaller cities that may have an opening by the time you graduate. If asked, feel free to mention my name.
The Dalles, OR
El Dorado, KS
Best of luck in your search!

answers.author: Barry Crook
answers.text:
I am a big believer in spending some early time in one's career in a budget office. Developing and administering the budget is a big part of managing a city government, it allows you to develop a deeper understanding of all the various lines of business a city is engaged in and all of the myriad policy issues you will later confront as a manager/assistant. If you are so inclined, find a larger community and start in their budget office.

answers.author: Leslie Beauregard
answers.text:
I don't know if you can afford to do this but I started as a volunteer in a small city's Finance Department.  From there, I was recommended for and obtained a paid internship in a larger City's Budget Office that was also close by.  That experience allowed me to demonstrate my commitment and the people I worked for recognized that and helped me secure a paid job when they had none to offer me...

answers.author: Randy Webster
answers.text:
I will second both Barry and Leslie. Spending a few years in the central budget office is invaluable. You learn how the allocation of scarce resources (the budget) really works, from the legal (GASB and local budget law), practical, policy (e.g. theory and best practice from GFOA and reality of implementation), programmatic, and political angles. It's a great foundation often leading to many options.

author: Casimir Caseneuve
text:
Hello all. I am graduating this year with my MPA. I have been doing some networking, going to the City Council meetings, emailed quite a few Mayors and City Managers with no luck. My ultimate goal is to land a position at a City Manager's Office.
Nonetheless at this point, getting a job in the Public Sector that will allow me to learn as much as possible is priority. Do you have any suggestions? links? anything that will put me on the right path.
Thank you so much, and I read some of you guys' profile, big congratulations to all that started with at least an internship so far... we are the future public servants.
Thanks in advance.
title: Landing an Internship/Job at the Office of Management & Budget
